column5: Hopefully on the way back on the 502 you'll have plenty of eyes on the road (walleyes ).

I've got a fly-in trip out of Red Lake scheduled for 8:00 AM Monday, and the two bait shops I called in Red Lake don't have leeches available. I'll be crossing the border around midnight, through Dryden about 3:00 AM, so I'm not sure what my options are if they aren't available in Red Lake. It's a private cabin, so I can't rely on an outfitter to source them. Anyone have a recommendation? I'm wondering if there are 24-hour gas stations that carry them by the lb? Or vending machines? I'd even pay in advance if anyone knows a bait guy that can leave them off the 502 for overnight pickup. Thanks in advance.

Leeches aren't a big thing right now.water getting colder and they'll roll up in a ball.Minnows are hot all season and are right now to.Buy them by the half gallon or gallon and have them bagged up at one Clark's bait shops.
Forget the Leeches ! They're done ! Minnows, Minnows, and more Minnows !
Buy some artificial leeches. I've used them and they work. They hold up pretty well too. PjShorthorn
Crawlers, crawlers n more crawlers,that's the cheapest route to go!

I can’t help you with the leeches but I will warn you that a couple of guys in camp mentioned they had 7 moose encounters on 502 during their night drive. I didn’t see any, but a coyote almost became a hood ornament on my truck.
Got to love the wildlife in Canada.
I sure enjoy the wildlife especially the walleye’s!
Berkely Power Leeches, not the Gulp ones, but the older models, great bait!! Bill

Thanks all. We’ve mainly used minnows but hard to keep alive all week, especially in warm water temps. Good to know crawlers are effective and will check into artificials.We take the 502 slow with an extra set of eyes on the road. Thanks for the reminder.
